column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#Text=[0067] These data indicate that the introduction of the carbon precursor at the preparation stage does not considerably affect the texture of the MgO phase.
#Text=The main difference here is in the organization of MgO nanoparticles in aggregates as shown in TEM images presented in FIGS. 4a and 4b.

#Text=It can be seen that carbon-coated samples (FIG. 4a) consist of many tiny spherical particles assembled into larger spheres while the AP--MgO (FIG. 4b) has a distinctly different, much more complex structure.
#Text=[0068] FIG. 5a presents high resolution TEM images of the AP--MgO sample.
#Text=At high magnification it can be seen that the sample consists of 4-6 nm crystallites arranged into chains forming a very porous secondary structure.
#Text=The abundance of pores of different sizes gives AP--MgO a high value of accessible surface area.
#Text=The C/MgO composite can be considered as interlinked MgO nanocrystals, covered by carbon, which does not significantly influence the texture of the MgO carcass.
#Text=Generally, this is confirmed by the high resolution image of the as-prepared C/MgO composite shown in FIG. 5b.
#Text=The MgO nanoparticles are covered by thin (thickness equivalent to 2-3 coplanar packed graphite monolayers) twisted carbon fragments (black lines on the image).
#Text=[0069] Catalytic properties of carbon-coated MgO aerogels were compared to those of AP--MgO using dehydrochlorination of 1-chlorobutane as a model reaction.
#Text=Recently, it has been shown that AP--MgO is active in this reaction, yielding HCl and butene isomers as reaction products (see, Mishakov et al., J.
#Text=Catal., 2002, 206, 40; Fenelonov et al., J.
#Text=Phys.
#Text=Chem.
#Text=B, 2001, 105, 3937, each incorporated by reference herein).
#Text=As the reaction proceeds, MgO is partially converted to MgCl.sub.2, and the resulting material appears to be a very active and stable catalyst.
#Text=Unfortunately, with unmodified MgO, this process is accompanied by a significant drop in the surface area.
#Text=[0070] FIG. 5 illustrates typical changes in 1-chlorobutane conversion with injection number.

#Text=The total of 10 injections corresponds to the molar amount of 1-chlorobutane exceeding that of the MgO in the catalyst by a factor of 2.5-4, depending upon the amount of carbonaceous residues in the latter.

#Text=It can be seen that the activity of a typical AP--MgO sample starts at a relatively low value and grows during the first 4-5 injections, in agreement with the fact that it undergoes partial conversion to MgCl.sub.2, the latter being a better catalyst.
#Text=[0071] Resorcinol-modified samples evacuated at 500.degree.
#Text=C. show an opposite behavior, i.e., the activity starts at a much higher value due to their higher surface area and then goes down.
#Text=Despite differences in the starting and final activities, this trend was the same for all resorcinol-modified samples activated at 500.degree.
#Text=C. studied.
#Text=Apparently, this temperature was not sufficient for complete conversion of organic groups on the MgO surface to carbon.
#Text=This is evidenced by the dark-brown color of the samples, elemental analysis data, and typical C--H stretches observed in the IR spectra.
#Text=According to the elemental analysis, Re--MgO-500 had 13.7 wt. % carbon and 1.8 wt. % hydrogen, the latter value being well above the amount typical for pure MgO nanoparticles.
#Text=It appears that these carbonaceous residues block more and more significant portion of the surface as the reaction goes on, thus limiting access to the catalytically active surface sites.
